tit.e: Shogatsu
Shogatsu
Shogatsu

sen.j: 正月（しょうがつ）とは、各暦の年の始めの数日間のことで、文化的には昨年が無事に終わったことと、新しい年を祝う行事である。
sen.e: Shogatsu refers to the first several days of a calendar year and, from the cultural viewpoint, an event to celebrate passing of the previous year which was uneventful, and the new year.
Shogatsu refers to the first several days of a calendar year and, from a cultural viewpoint, an event to celebrate passing of the previous year, which was uneventful, and the new year.
Shogatsu refers to the first several days of a calendar year and, from a cultural viewpoint, an event to celebrate passing of the previous year, which was uneventful, and the new year.

sen.j: 正月行事を行ったり正月料理を食べて、盛大に祝う。
sen.e: During shogatsu, people actively and gorgeously celebrate the new year attending shogatsu events and enjoying shogatsu dishes.
During shogatsu, people actively and gorgeously celebrate the new year by attending shogatsu events and enjoying shogatsu dishes.
During shogatsu, people actively and gorgeously celebrate the new year by attending shogatsu events and enjoying shogatsu dishes.

sen.j: 日本では、1月1日の元日のみを国民の祝日としているが、実際には少なくとも1月3日までの三箇日（場合によってはそれ以後の数日間も）を「お正月」と呼んで、事実上の祝日と同じ状態となる。
sen.e: In Japan, though only the New Year's Day, January 1st is a national holiday, at least the period, sanganichi (the three days) until January 3rd (sometimes, including the several days following it) is actually called 'o-shogatsu (a polite form of shogatsu)' and this period is substantially a holiday period.

In Japan, although only New Year's Day, January 1st, is a national holiday, at least the period of sanganichi (the three days) through January 3rd (sometimes including several days following it) is substantially a holiday period, and is actually called 'o-shogatsu' (a polite form of shogatsu).

In Japan, although only New Year's Day, January 1st, is a national holiday, at least the period of sanganichi (the three days) through January 3rd (sometimes including several days following it) is substantially a holiday period, and is actually called 'o-shogatsu' (a polite form of shogatsu).

sen.j: 日本の正月
sen.e: Shogatsu in Japan
Shogatsu in Japan
Shogatsu in Japan

sen.j: 「正月」とは、本来1月の別名だが、現在は1月1日から1月3日まで（三が日＝さんがにち）、または「松の内」（元々は1月15日まで、現在は一部では7日まで）を指すことが多い。
sen.e: Though 'shogatsu' is originally another name of January, shogatsu often refers to a period from January 1st to January 3rd (sanganichi) or 'matsu-no-uchi (this period is originally until January 15th while until 7th for some people currently).

Although 'shogatsu' is originally another name for January, shogatsu often refers to a period from January 1st to January 3rd (sanganichi) or 'matsu-no-uchi (this period is originally through January 15th, but currently through January 7th for some people).

Although 'shogatsu' is originally another name for January, shogatsu often refers to a period from January 1st to January 3rd (sanganichi) or 'matsu-no-uchi (this period is originally through January 15th, but currently through January 7th for some people.)

sen.j: また、1月20日までを正月とすることもあり、1月20日を二十日正月（骨正月）と呼ぶ。
sen.e: For some people, shogatsu refers to a period from January 1st to January 20th and January 20th is called hatsuka- (20th of a month) shogatsu (hone- (bone) shogatsu).
For some people, shogatsu refers to a period from January 1st to January 20th, and January 20th is called hatsuka- (20th of a month) shogatsu (hone- (bone) shogatsu).
For some people, shogatsu refers to a period from January 1st to January 20th, and January 20th is called hatsuka- (20th of a month) shogatsu (hone- [bone] shogatsu).
sen.cmt: 括弧内の括弧を[]に変更

sen.j: 新暦の元日を軸とする「大正月」（おおしょうがつ）と旧暦の15日を軸とする小正月（こしょうがつ）と呼ぶものがある。
sen.e: There are two kinds of shogatsu which are: 'oh-shogatsu (large shogatsu)' which is based on the New Year's Day according to the solar calendar; and 'ko-shogatsu (small shogatsu)' which is based on January 15th according to the lunar calendar.

There are two kinds of shogatsu, which are: 'oh-shogatsu (large shogatsu)' which is based on New Year's Day according to the solar calendar; and 'ko-shogatsu (small shogatsu)' which is based on January 15th according to the lunar calendar.

There are two kinds of shogatsu, which are: 'oh-shogatsu' (large shogatsu) which is based on New Year's Day according to the solar calendar; and 'ko-shogatsu' (small shogatsu) which is based on January 15th according to the lunar calendar.
sen.cmt: 「oh-shogatsu」は「お正月」と区別するために、「oh」のままとします。' ' の位置を「」の部分に変更

sen.j: 大正月はまた大年（おおどし）、男の正月と呼ぶのに対して、小正月を小年（こどし）、女の正月と言うところもある。
sen.e: In some areas, oh-shogatsu is also called oh-doshi (large year) and otoko no shogatsu (men's shogatsu) and, in contrast, ko-shogatsu is called ko-doshi (small year) and onna no shogatsu (women's shogatsu).

In some areas, oh-shogatsu is also called oh-doshi (large year) and otoko no shogatsu (men's shogatsu) and, in contrast, ko-shogatsu is called ko-doshi (small year) and onna no shogatsu (women's shogatsu).

sen.j: 12月8日（関西では13日）を「正月事始め」と称して、正月準備が始まる。
sen.e: January 8th (13th in Kansai Region) is called 'shogatsu-kotohajime (start of things for shogatsu)' and people start preparation for shogatsu.
January 8th (January 13th in the Kansai Region) is called 'shogatsu-kotohajime (start of things for shogatsu)' and people start preparation for shogatsu.
January 8th (January 13th in the Kansai Region) is called 'shogatsu-kotohajime' (start of things for shogatsu) and people start preparation for shogatsu.

sen.j: 1月1日を元日、元日の朝を元旦（がんたん）と呼ぶ。
sen.e: January 1st is called ganjitsu and the morning of gantan is called gantan.
January 1st is called ganjitsu, and the morning of ganjitsu is called gantan.
sen.cmt: word choicetrans 1 had "gantan" where "ganjitsu" probably should be used.
sen.e: January 1st is called ganjitsu, and the morning of ganjitsu is called gantan.

sen.j: 元日は国民の祝日となっているが、官公庁は12月29日から1月3日までを休日としており、一般企業でもこれに準じていることが多い（銀行などの金融機関は、12月31日から1月3日までを（現金自動預け払い機等を除いて）休日とすることが多く、システムメンテナンスを行うため長くなる事もある）。
sen.e: Though only ganjitsu is a national holiday, the governmental offices are closed from December 29th to January 3rd and many ordinary companies follow this schedule and close during this period (while many financial institutions such as banks are closed from December 31 to January 3rd (except their ATMs, etc.) and this period may be extended for system maintenance).

Although only ganjitsu is a national holiday, governmental offices are closed from December 29th to January 3rd and many ordinary companies follow this schedule and close during this period (while many financial institutions such as banks are closed from December 31 to January 3rd (except their ATMs, etc.) and this period may be extended for system maintenance).

Although only ganjitsu is a national holiday, governmental offices are closed from December 29th to January 3rd and many ordinary companies follow this schedule and close during this period (while many financial institutions such as banks are closed from December 31 to January 3rd [except their ATMs, etc.] and this period may be extended for system maintenance.)
sen.cmt: 括弧内の括弧を[]に変更ピリオドを括弧内へ移動

sen.j: このため、公共交通機関はこの期間中は平日も含めて休日ダイヤで運行する傾向にある。
sen.e: Therefore， the ｐublic transｐortation tends to operate based on the holiday schedule during this period including weekdays.
Therefore， the ｐublic transｐortation tends to operate based on the holiday schedule during this period including weekdays.
Therefore, the public transportation tends to operate based on the holiday schedule during this period including weekdays.
sen.cmt: 文頭部分が全角のようでしたので、訂正しました。

sen.j: 一方、小売業では、1970年代頃までは松の内（関東）の頃（1月5～7日）まで休業していた店が多かったが、24時間営業のコンビニエンスストアの登場などの生活様式の変化により、開店日は早くなり、1990年代以降は元日のみ休業し、翌1月2日から短時間体制での営業を始める店が多い。
sen.e: On the other hand, many retail stores used to be closed until around the end of matsu no uchi (January 5th to 7th) until 1970s (in Kanto Region) while the day in the new year on which retail stores started their operation became earlier due to the change of the people's life style such as the appearance of convenience stores which operate for 24 hours and, therefore, in and after 1990s, many stores started their operation on the next day, January 2nd on a fewer-hours basis.

On the other hand, until the 1970s (in the Kanto region) many retail stores used to be closed until around the end of matsu no uchi (January 5th to 7th), while the day in the new year on which retail stores started their operation became earlier due to the change of the people's lifestyles such as the appearance of convenience stores which operate 24 hours a day and, therefore, in and after the 1990s, many stores started their operation on the next day, January 2nd on a fewer-hours basis.

On the other hand, until the 1970s (in the Kanto region) many retail stores used to be closed until around the end of matsu no uchi (January 5th to 7th), while the day in the new year on which retail stores started their operation became earlier due to the change of the people's lifestyles such as the appearance of convenience stores which operate 24 hours a day and, therefore, in and after the 1990s, many stores started their operation on the next day, January 2nd on a fewer-hours basis.

sen.j: 大型店など店舗によっては、短時間体制ながらも元日も営業することも多くなった。
sen.e: Some types of stores such as large-scale stores which also operate on ganjitsu has increased.
More and more types of stores such as large-scale stores have also come to operate on ganjitsu.
More and more types of stores such as large-scale stores have also come to operate on ganjitsu though on a fewer-hours basis.
sen.cmt: 「短時間体制ながらも」 訳漏れ対応しました。

sen.j: ほとんどの場合は1月4日ごろから平常営業に戻る。
sen.e: Most of such stores return to their normal operation on around January 4th.
Most of such stores return to their normal operation on around January 4th.
Most of such stores return to their normal operation on around January 4th.

sen.j: かつては夏のお盆と対応して、半年ごとに先祖を祀る行事であった。
sen.e: In the old days, shogatsu used to be an event to deify the ancestors every half a year in response to o-bon in summer.
In the old days, shogatsu used to be an event to deify one's ancestors every half a year, along with o-bon in summer.
In the old days, shogatsu used to be an event to deify one's ancestors every half a year, along with o-bon in summer.

sen.j: しかし、仏教の影響が強くなるにつれ、盆は仏教行事の盂蘭盆と習合して先祖供養の行事とし、対する正月は歳徳神を迎えてその年の豊作を祈る「神祭り」として位置付けられるようになった。
sen.e: However, as the influence of Buddhism became stronger, bon was combined with urabon which is a Buddhism event and became an event to hold a memorial service for the ancestors while shogatsu was positioned to be a 'kami matsuri (god festival)' to prey for rich harvest of the year welcoming toshitoku-shin god (a god who controls the happiness of the year).

However, as the influence of Buddhism became stronger, bon was combined with urabon, which is a Buddhist event, and became an event to hold a memorial service for one's ancestors while shogatsu was positioned to be a 'kami matsuri (god festival)' to pray for rich harvest of the year welcoming toshitoku-shin god (a god who controls the happiness of the year).

However, as the influence of Buddhism became stronger, bon was combined with urabon, which is a Buddhist event, and became an event to hold a memorial service for one's ancestors while shogatsu was positioned to be a 'kami matsuri' (god festival) to pray for rich harvest of the year welcoming toshitoku-shin god (a god who controls the happiness of the year).

sen.j: 数え年では1月1日に歳を1つ加えていたことから、正月は無事に歳を重ねられたことを祝うものでもあった。
sen.e: Because kazoedoshi (a calendar-year age) is increased by one on January 1st, shogatsu also used to be an event to celebrate a safe increase of people's age.
Because kazoedoshi (a calendar-year age) is increased by one on January 1st, shogatsu also used to be an event to celebrate a safe increase of people's age.
Because kazoedoshi (a calendar-year age) is increased by one on January 1st, shogatsu also used to be an event to celebrate a safe increase of people's age.

sen.j: 満年齢を使うようになってからはそのような意味合いはなくなり、単に年が変わったこと（新年）を祝う行事となっている。
sen.e: Shogatsu lost such a meaning when people started to use the age based on the length of time from the birth, and shogatsu became an event to celebrate only the change of the calendar year (to welcome the new year).

Shogatsu lost such a meaning when people started to use the age based on the length of time from their birth, and shogatsu became an event to celebrate only the change of the calendar year (to welcome the new year).

Shogatsu lost such a meaning when people started to use the age based on the length of time from their birth, and shogatsu became an event to celebrate only the change of the calendar year (to welcome the new year).

sen.j: 欧米では1月1日のみ休日で、翌1月2日から金融市場などは平常業務を開始する。
sen.e: In Europe and the US, only January 1st is a holiday and financial markets, etc., start their normal operation on the next day, January 2nd.

sen.j: 正月はクリスマス休暇（12月24日～1月1日）中の一つのイベントと位置づけられている。
sen.e: Shogatsu is positioned to be one of the events held during the Christmas holidays (December 24th to January 1st).
Shogatsu is positioned to be one of the events held during the Christmas holidays (December 24th to January 1st).

sen.j: 軍隊も戦闘中でない全将兵が休暇として帰宅させられキャンプや基地は閉鎖される。
sen.e: As to armies, all the officers and soldiers who are not in engagement are returned home as their leave and camps and bases are closed.
As to armed forces, all officers and soldiers who are not in engagement are returned home as their leave and camps and bases are closed.

sen.j: 1月1日：殆どの国で、グレゴリオ暦の初日が設定されている。
sen.e: January 1st: the first day of the Gregorian calendar is set to be this day in most of the countries.
January 1st: the first day of the Gregorian calendar is set to be this day in most countries.
January 1st: the first day of the Gregorian calendar is set to be this day in most countries.

sen.j: ユダヤ暦、ローシュ・ハッシャーナーは過越の後163日目に祝う、現在のグレゴリオ暦では9月5日より前にはならず（9月5日になったのは、以前は1899年、次は2033年）、2089年以降は9月6日以前にはならない。
sen.e: Ros haSanah of the Jewish calendar is celebrated 163 days after the passing to the new year and, in the current Gregorian calendar, this does not fall on September 5th and any day before it (it last fell on September 5th in 1899 and will next fall on in 2033) and will not fall on September 6th or any day before it in and after 2089.

Ros haSanah of the Jewish calendar is celebrated 163 days after the passing to the new year and, in the current Gregorian calendar, this does not fall on September 5th and any day before it (it last fell on September 5th in 1899 and will next fall on in 2033) and will not fall on September 6th or any day before it in and after 2089.

Ros haSanah of the Jewish calendar is celebrated 163 days after the passing to the new year and, in the current Gregorian calendar, this does not fall on September 5th and any day before it (it last fell on September 5th in 1899 and will next fall on in 2033) and will not fall on September 6th or any day before it in and after 2089.

sen.j: ローシュ・ハッシャーナーは10月5日以降にはならない（10月5日になったのは、以前1967年、次回2043年） 参照：ユダヤ暦
sen.e: Ros haSanah does not fall on October 5th and any day after it (it last fell on October 5th in 1967 and will next fall on in 2043) (see the Jewish calendar).
Ros haSanah does not fall on October 5th and any day after it (it last fell on October 5th in 1967 and will next fall on in 2043) (see the Jewish calendar).

sen.j: 1月14日（ユリウス暦の1月1日）：正教会； 正教会の国々は、ユリウス暦の正月を宗教的休日・旧正月として、グレゴリオ暦の正月を法的な休日として、両方を祝う。
sen.e: January 14th (January 1st of the Julian calendar): Orthodox Church; in the countries of the Orthodox Church, people celebrate both of the New Year's Day of the Julius calendar as a religious holiday and the old New Year's Day, and the New Year's Day of the Gregorian calendar as a legal holiday.

January 14th (January 1st of the Julian calendar): Orthodox Church; in the countries of the Orthodox Church, people celebrate both the New Year's Day of the Julian calendar as a religious holiday and the old New Year's Day, and the New Year's Day of the Gregorian calendar as a legal holiday.

January 14th (January 1st of the Julian calendar): Orthodox Church; in the countries of the Orthodox Church, people celebrate both the New Year's Day of the Julian calendar as a religious holiday and the old New Year's Day, and the New Year's Day of the Gregorian calendar as a legal holiday.

sen.j: 現在半数以上の正教会は、改訂ユリウス暦を採用し、1月1日に正月を祝う。
sen.e: Currently, more than a half of the Orthodox Churches employ the revised Julius calendar and celebrate the New Year's Day on January 1st.
Currently, more than a half of the Orthodox Churches employ the revised Julian calendar and celebrate New Year's Day on January 1st.
Currently, more than a half of the Orthodox Churches employ the revised Julian calendar and celebrate New Year's Day on January 1st.

sen.j: コプト正教会では、Neyrouz （正月）は1900年から2099年の間は、グレゴリオ暦9月11日、閏年は9月12日に新年を祝う。
sen.e: Kobut Orthodox Church celebrates their Neyrouz (the New Year's Day) on September 11th of the Gregorian calendar during 1900 and 2099 and celebrates the new year on September 12th of the Gregorian calendar in intercalary years.

The Kobut Orthodox Church celebrates their Neyrouz (New Year's Day) on September 11th of the Gregorian calendar during 1900 and 2099 and celebrates the new year on September 12th of the Gregorian calendar in intercalary years.

The Kobut Orthodox Church celebrates their Neyrouz (New Year's Day) on September 11th of the Gregorian calendar during 1900 and 2099 and celebrates the new year on September 12th of the Gregorian calendar in intercalary years.

sen.j: 名称はペルシア語で正月にあたる春分のノウルーズ Nawrūz に由来する（イラン暦）。
sen.e: This name is originated from Nawrūz, the vernal equinox which means the New Year Day in Persian (the Iranian calendar).
This name is originated from Nawrūz, the vernal equinox which means New Year's Day in Persian (the Iranian calendar).
This name is originated from Nawrūz, the vernal equinox which means New Year's Day in Persian (the Iranian calendar).

sen.j: コプト暦の場合、日時の由来は春分のナウルーズと対になる秋分のミフラガーン Mihragān にあたる。
sen.e: In Kobut calendar, the origin of the date and the time corresponds to Mihragān, the autumnal equinox which is the counterpart of the vernal equinox.
In the Kobut calendar, the origin of the date and the time corresponds to Mihragān, the autumnal equinox, which is the counterpart of the vernal equinox.

sen.j: コプト暦1723年は、グレゴリオ2005年9月に始まる。
sen.e: 1723 in the Kobut calendar started in September 2005.
1723 in the Kobut calendar started in September 2005.

sen.j: エチオピア正教会（エチオピア暦）は、コプト教と同じ9月11日が Enkutatash（正月）になる；グレゴリオ暦2005年は、エチオピア暦1998年。
sen.e: For the Ethiopian Orthodox Church (the Ethiopian calendar), September 11 is Enkutatash (the New Year's Day) similarly to that of the Kobut; 2005 in the Gregorian calendar falls on 1998 in the Ethiopian calendar.

sen.j: Thelema では、Heru-ra-ha と共に、現イーオン（Aeon、現在は3番目の Aeon で、Aeon of Horus, グレゴリオ1904年より）を祝う。
sen.e: In Thelema, the current Aeon (the current one is the third Aeon and started from Aeon of Horus which was 1904 in the Gregorian calendar) is celebrated together with Heru-ra-ha.

tit.e: China and Eastern world

sen.j: 中国暦（太陰太陽暦）：グレゴリオ暦1月21日～2月21日の間の新月の日が、春節。
sen.e: Chinese calendar (the lunar and solar calendar): the day of a new moon between January 21st and February 21st in the Gregorian calendar is chun-jie (in Chinese), the Chinese New Year's Day.
Chinese calendar (the lunar and solar calendar): the day of a new moon between January 21st and February 21st in the Gregorian calendar is chun-jie (in Chinese), the Chinese New Year's Day.
Chinese calendar (the lunar and solar calendar): the day of a new moon between January 21st and February 21st in the Gregorian calendar is chun-jie (in Chinese), the Chinese New Year's Day.

sen.j: 中国暦はグレゴリオ暦と異なり、天体の月の運行により天文学的に決められる為に約1か月の間で移動がある。
sen.e: The Chinese calendar differs from the Gregorian calendar and is astronomically determined based on the revolution of the moon and, therefore, the New Year's Day moves within the range of about one month.
The Chinese calendar differs from the Gregorian calendar and is astronomically determined based on the revolution of the moon and, therefore, New Year's Day moves within the range of about one month.

sen.j: 十干十二支の60年サイクルで各年に12種類の動物と10種類の要素の組み合わせ（干支）の名前が付けられる。
sen.e: In a cycle of 60 years based on the ten celestial signs and the twelve horary signs, each year is named a combination of one of the 12 kinds of animals and one of the ten kinds of elements (eto).
In a cycle of 60 years based on the ten celestial signs and the twelve horary signs, each year is named a combination of one of the 12 kinds of animals and one of the ten kinds of elements (eto).
In a cycle of 60 years based on the ten celestial signs and the twelve horary signs, each year is named a combination of one of the 12 kinds of animals and one of the ten kinds of elements (eto).

sen.j: 中国大陸・台湾・大韓民国において重要なのは旧正月であるが、元日も法定休日になっており、中国・台湾では「元旦」（1912年以前）と呼ばれ、1日の休日、韓国においては「新正」と呼ばれ、1日の休日となっている。
sen.e: Though the Chinese New Year is important in mainland China, Taiwan, and Korea, January 1st is also their legal holiday and January 1st used to be called 'yuan-dan' in Chinese (which corresponds to the above gantan) in mainland China and Taiwan (in and before 1912), and is a holiday for one whole day and is called 'shinsho' in Korean in Korea and is a holiday for one whole day.

Although the Chinese New Year is important in mainland China, Taiwan, and Korea, January 1st is also their legal holiday and January 1st used to be called 'yuan-dan' in Chinese (which corresponds to the above gantan) in mainland China and Taiwan (in and before 1912), and is a holiday for one whole day and is called 'shinsho' in Korean in Korea and is a holiday for one whole day.

Although the Chinese New Year is important in mainland China, Taiwan, and Korea, January 1st is also their legal holiday and January 1st used to be called 'yuan-dan' in Chinese (which corresponds to the above gantan) in mainland China and Taiwan (in and before 1912), and is a holiday for one whole day and is called 'shinsho' in Korean in Korea and is a holiday for one whole day.

sen.j: 香港やシンガポールなど中国系文化圏でも、旧暦の正月にお祝いをすることがほとんどである。
sen.e: In the Chinese culture area such as Hong Kong and Singapore, people celebrate the new year according to the lunar calendar in most cases.

sen.j: 紀元前713年頃、Numa Pompilius により January と February が加えられ、1 January が正月（年の暦は、January から December、現代英語を含むラテン語派生系言語の7月から12月は、ラテン語：（例として英語では）September, 7番目、October, 8番目、November, 9番目、December, 10番目、の意味））になったが、執政官には紀元前153年まで使われなかった。
sen.e: In around B.C. 713, January and February were added by Numa Pompilius and January 1st became the New Year's Day while this system had not been used by governmental officers until B.C. 153 (the yearly calendar was revised to that starting from January and ending with December and the seventh to the twelfth months named in a language branched from the Latin became names in Latin such as (in English as examples): September (meaning the seventh), October (meaning the eighth), November (meaning the ninth), and December (meaning the tenth)).

sen.j: 紀元前45年、ユリウス・カエサルがユリウス暦（閏年が無い）を導入、1 January がグレゴリオ暦同様、正月（新年初日）になった。
sen.e: In B.C. 45, Julius Caesar introduced the Julius calendar (which had no intercalary year) and, similarly to the Gregorian calendar, January 1st became the New Year's Day (the first day of the new year).
In B.C. 45, Julius Caesar introduced the Julian calendar (which had no intercalary year) and, similar to the Gregorian calendar, January 1st became New Year's Day (the first day of the new year).

sen.j: 後にイギリスはユリウス暦からグレゴリオ暦となるが、現在でもイギリスの税制年度は4月6日（3月25日＋12日；11日はユリウス暦から、グレゴリオ暦への差日分、＋1日は1900年の閏日）を新年としている。
sen.e: Later on, Great Britain changed its calendar from the Julius calendar to the Gregorian calendar while, even today, the taxation year has its new year's day on April 6th (which is March 25th plus 12 days of which 11 days are the difference generated by the change from the Julius calendar to the Gregorian calendar and one more day is an intercalary day of the year 1900).

sen.j: 中華人民共和国、大韓民国、台湾、ベトナムなどでは、新暦の正月よりも旧正月の方が重視され、お年玉もこの日に渡される。
sen.e: In countries such as the People's Republic of China, Korea, Taiwan, and Vietnam, the old new year is more important than the new year of the new calendar and the new year's gift money is presented on this day.

In countries such as the People's Republic of China, Korea, Taiwan, and Vietnam, the old new year is more important than the new year of the new calendar and the new year's gift money is presented on this day.

In countries such as the People's Republic of China, Korea, Taiwan, and Vietnam, the old new year is more important than the new year of the new calendar and the new year's gift money is presented on this day.

sen.j: 中国では「春節」、「過年」、「農暦新年」といい、ベトナムでは「テト」といわれる。
sen.e: The new year's day is called in Chinese 'chun-jie (spring festival)', 'guo-nian (passing of a year)', and 'nong-li-xin-nian (the new year's day of the agricultural calendar)' in mainland China, and is called 'teto' in Vietnamese in Vietnam.

The new year's day is called in Chinese 'chun-jie (spring festival)', 'guo-nian (passing of a year)', and 'nong-li-xin-nian (the new year's day of the agricultural calendar)' in mainland China, and is called 'teto' in Vietnamese in Vietnam.

The new year's day is called in Chinese 'chun-jie' (spring festival', 'guo-nian' (passing of a year), and 'nong-li-xin-nian' (the new year's day of the agricultural calendar) in mainland China, and is called 'teto' in Vietnamese in Vietnam.

sen.j: テトとは「節」という漢字のベトナム語読みに相当する。
sen.e: The word 'teto' corresponds to the reading in Vietnamese of a Chinese character 'jie (meaning festival)'.
The word 'teto' corresponds to the reading in Vietnamese of a Chinese character 'jie (meaning festival)'.
The word 'teto' corresponds to the reading in Vietnamese of a Chinese character 'jie' (meaning festival).

sen.j: また、旧暦1月 (旧暦)のことを「正月」と呼び（旧暦では「正月」が正式名、「1月」が異名である）、旧正月を「正旦」ともいう。
sen.e: January (the old calendar) of the old calendar is called 'shogatsu' (in the old calendar, 'shogatsu' is the formal name and 'ichi-gatsu (meaning January)' is another name), and the kyu-shogatsu (the old new year's day) is also called 'shotan'.

January (the old calendar) of the old calendar is called 'shogatsu' (in the old calendar, 'shogatsu' is the formal name and 'ichi-gatsu (meaning January)' is another name), and the kyu-shogatsu (the old new year's day) is also called 'shotan'.

January (the old calendar) of the old calendar is called 'shogatsu' (in the old calendar, 'shogatsu' is the formal name and 'ichi-gatsu' [meaning January] is another name), and the kyu-shogatsu (the old new year's day) is also called 'shotan'.
sen.cmt: 「」部分に ' '括弧内の括弧を[]に変更

sen.j: 日本でも沖縄県や鹿児島県の奄美諸島などの一部地域では旧正月を祝う地方がある。
sen.e: In Japan, people celebrate kyu-shogatsu in some areas such as Okinawa Prefecture, Amami Islands in Kagoshima Prefecture.
In Japan, people celebrate kyu-shogatsu in some areas such as Okinawa Prefecture and the Amami Islands in Kagoshima Prefecture.
In Japan, people celebrate kyu-shogatsu in some areas such as Okinawa Prefecture and the Amami Islands in Kagoshima Prefecture.

sen.j: 正月に関する諺
sen.e: Sayings concerning shogatsu
Sayings concerning shogatsu
Sayings concerning shogatsu

sen.j: 正月は冥土の旅の一里塚（門松は冥土の旅の一里塚ともいい、「めでたくもあり、めでたくもなし」と続く。
sen.e: Shogatsu is also said to be a milepost for the trip to the other world (this is otherwise "kadomatsu (a decoration for the new year made of pine branches, etc.) is a milestone for the trip to the other world" and both of the saying has the following phrase as their latter half: it should be celebrated and should not be.

Shogatsu is also said to be a milepost for the trip to the other world (this is otherwise "kadomatsu (a decoration for the new year made of pine branches, etc.) is a milestone for the trip to the other world" and both of the sayings have the following phrase as their latter half: it should be celebrated and should not be.

Shogatsu is also said to be a milepost for the trip to the other world (this is otherwise kadomatsu [a decoration for the new year made of pine branches, etc.] is a milestone for the trip to the other world) and both of the sayings have the following phrase as their latter half: it should be celebrated and should not be.

sen.j: 一休の作と伝えられる）
sen.e: It is said that this saying was created by Ikkyu, a Buddhism monk.
It is said that this saying was created by Ikkyu, a Buddhist monk.

sen.j: 正月買い（正月に遊女などを買うと祝儀など余分な費用がかかる）
sen.e: Shogatsu-gai (new year shopping): when a man plays with a prostitute in a licensed quarter in shogatsu, extra expenses such as a money gift are necessary.
